metadata.case_name: Appellant (Election Petitioner) v. K. Brahmananda Reddy

facts.text: General Elections held in February 1962 for Legislative Assembly Constituency of Phirangipuram in Guntur District, Andhra Pradesh.
Third respondent K. Brahmananda Reddy and second respondent Chandramouli were contesting candidates.
Polling took place on 26th February 1962; Returning Officer declared Brahmananda Reddy elected with majority of valid votes.
Appellant, a voter on the rolls of the constituency, filed Election Petition before Election Commission on 11 April 1962 under s.81 of Representation of the Peoples Act, 1951.
Petition accompanied by requisite number of copies and treasury receipt for security deposit under s.117.
Grounds: corrupt practices by returned candidate and agent, irregularities like votes of dead voters and double voting.
Election Commission published copy of petition in Official Gazette on 17 May 1962 under s.86.
Election Tribunal constituted; petition referred for trial.
Returned candidate filed Written Statement on 15 September 1962 denying allegations and raising technical objections.
On 24 September 1962, returned candidate filed further statement of objections, including para 2 alleging non-compliance with s.81(3) as copies not attested as true copies.
Tribunal ordered decision on preliminary objections on 7 November 1962, deciding in favour of petitioner.
Returned candidate filed Writ Petition under Article 226 in Andhra Pradesh High Court seeking quashing of Tribunal's order and dismissal of petition.
High Court by judgment dated 15 April 1963 allowed writ, dismissed Election Petition for non-compliance with s.81(3).

Precise defect: Petition type-written, carbon copies accompanied; copies bore two original signatures of petitioner authenticating contents and verification, but without words 'true copy' before or above signatures.
Appellant obtained special leave; filed this appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Election Petition complied with s.81(3) of the Representation of the Peoples Act, 1951, requiring copies to be attested by petitioner under his signature to be a true copy, absent the words 'true copy' despite signatures authenticating contents.
Whether non-compliance with s.81(3) mandates dismissal under s.90(3), or if substantial compliance suffices.

petitioner_arguments.text: Substantial compliance with s.81(3) as copies were exact carbon copies, bore petitioner's original signatures authenticating contents and verification.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Sheo Ram Jaiswal; Kamaraj Nadar

petitioner_arguments.text: Defect in copy accompanying petition does not attract s.90(3); only defects in petition itself do; difference in language of s.85 and s.90(3).

respondent_arguments.text: Strict literal compliance mandatory; absence of words 'true copy' before signature means no attestation; imperative 'shall' in s.81(3).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.81(3), s.90(3) RPA; history of 1961 amendment

respondent_arguments.text: Object of s.81(3): expedite process, avoid Commission making copies; respondents need assertion on face that copies are true.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Noseworthy v. Overseers; Spice v. Bacon

respondent_arguments.text: Signature only copies original signature, not animo attestendi without words 'true copy'.

court_reasoning.text: Election petitions statutory; mandatory requirements not dispensable, but substantial compliance suffices if copy substantially true, no material variation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Signature authenticates contents; no need for refinement; substantial compliance present.

court_reasoning.text: s.81(3) part of presentation requirements; non-compliance could invoke s.85 or s.90(3), but here copies exact, signed originally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Murarka case: 'copy' means substantially true, not exact replica.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred; signatures appended animo attestendi; even if positions swapped, substantial compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence needed; context shows authentication of copy.

court_reasoning.text: Strictness for expedition, but not to defeat purity of elections.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Kamaraj Nadar: deposit substantially complied despite minor error.

holdings.text: Substantial compliance with s.81(3) where exact carbon copies signed by petitioner authenticating contents, even without 'true copy' words.
s.90(3) not attracted; Tribunal/High Court cannot dismiss for substantial compliance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Sheo Ram Jaiswal
precedents_cited.relevance: Copy means substantially true, not exact; defects like missing signature copy or verification omission not fatal.
Substantial compliance with s.117 deposit suffices despite minor error.
Strict notice compliance; not general rule for all statutes.
Incomplete copy not 'copy'; turned on material omission.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the Peoples Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs presentation, contents, trial, dismissal of election petitions; s.81(3) requires attested copies.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction; elections questioned only by petition per law.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to verification of petition and annexures per s.83.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; Election Petition directed to proceed to trial on merits expeditiously.
outcome.relief_granted: Election Petition maintainable; to be tried on merits.

key_quotes.text: "By copy in s.81(3) was meant not an exact copy but only one so true that nobody by any possibility misunderstands it not being the same as the original."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'true copy' standard from Murarka case.

key_quotes.text: "No doubt, what is necessary is a substantial compliance with the requirement of attestation. For instance, if it is proved that the election petitioner has signed animo attestendi, and omitted the words true copy by mistake or inadvertently, there is a substantial compliance."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court observation adopted, applied to facts.

key_quotes.text: "If the signature of the petitioner whose name is set out in the body of the petition is appended at the end, surely it authenticates the contents of the document."
key_quotes.speaker: court
